trans-unit.id: Level 1 support for a Dutch photo club

Caption of 3D image on Readme page

trans-unit.id: No photo clubs seem to be currently loaded. Try dragging down the Photo Clubs screen to reload the default clubs.
trans-unit.source: No photo clubs seem to be currently loaded. Try dragging down the Photo Clubs screen to reload the default clubs.
trans-unit.target: No photo clubs seem to be currently loaded. Try dragging down the Photo Clubs screen to reload the default clubs.
trans-unit.note: Hint to the user if the database returns zero PhotoClubs.
Shown below map if there is no usable remark in the OrganzationList.json file.
Section title on Readme page

trans-unit.source: Our ambitions in creating _Photo Club Hub_ were to strengthen ties between photography clubs, and making the work of club members easier to access.
trans-unit.target: Our ambitions in creating _Photo Club Hub_ were to strengthen ties between photography clubs, and making the work of club members easier to access.
trans-unit.note: First paragraph in The App section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: _Photo Club Hub_ showcases selected photos by members of participating clubs. The photos are displayed in a consistent, easy to access way, with minimal distractions.
trans-unit.target: _Photo Club Hub_ showcases selected photos by members of participating clubs. The photos are displayed in a consistent, easy to access way, with minimal distractions.
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph in The App section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: This consistency avoids having to find each club's website yourself, and then figuring out how to locate and browse the photos on that site. The app does __not__ try to replace club web sites, photographer web sites, or social media channels. Instead, it supports clubs and their members who try to reach out to other clubs, other photographers, and a general audience.
trans-unit.target: This consistency avoids having to find each club's website yourself, and then figuring out how to locate and browse the photos on that site. The app does __not__ try to replace club web sites, photographer web sites, or social media channels. Instead, it supports clubs and their members who try to reach out to other clubs, other photographers, and a general audience.
trans-unit.note: Third paragraph in The App section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The app was originally named _Photo Club Waalre_ after a 15-person photo club in the southern Netherlands. The word __hub__ in the new name stresses the app's support for __multiple__ photo clubs.
trans-unit.target: The app was originally named _Photo Club Waalre_ after a 15-person photo club in the southern Netherlands. The word __hub__ in the new name stresses the app's support for __multiple__ photo clubs.
trans-unit.note: Fourth paragraph in The App section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Supporting dozens or even hundreds of clubs requires that each club manages its own data. This includes providing images, and maintaining lists of club members. Adding a club to _Photo Club Hub_ does not require software expertise.
trans-unit.target: Supporting dozens or even hundreds of clubs requires that each club manages its own data. This includes providing images, and maintaining lists of club members. Adding a club to _Photo Club Hub_ does not require software expertise.
trans-unit.note: Fifth paragraph in The App section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Interested in adding support for your club? Contact us via [GitHub](https://github.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub), [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/vdhamer) or [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/vdhamer/). Adding your club only involves providing and updating club data in a way that the app can understand. The app's [GitHub site](https://GitHub.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub#readme) explains the strategy and approach in more detail. We are here to help if you have any questions.
trans-unit.target: Interested in adding support for your club? Contact us via [GitHub](https://github.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub), [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/vdhamer) or [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/vdhamer/). Adding your club only involves providing and updating club data in a way that the app can understand. The app's [GitHub site](https://GitHub.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub#readme) explains the strategy and approach in more detail. We are here to help if you have any questions.
trans-unit.note: Sixth paragraph in The App section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Photo clubs play a central role in this app. The _Portfolios_ screen shows a list of photo clubs.
trans-unit.target: Photo clubs play a central role in this app. The _Portfolios_ screen shows a list of photo clubs.
trans-unit.note: First paragraph in The Concept on Readme page

trans-unit.source: Each photo club contains a series of member __portfolios__ that hold the actual images. Each portfolio covers the photographer's photos that are associated with that photo club.
trans-unit.target: Each photo club contains a series of member __portfolios__ that hold the actual images. Each portfolio covers the photographer's photos that are associated with that photo club.
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph in The Concept on Readme page

trans-unit.source: A photographer may have multiple portfolios in the app in case the photographer is (or was) associated with more than one photo club.
trans-unit.target: A photographer may have multiple portfolios in the app in case the photographer is (or was) associated with more than one photo club.
trans-unit.note: Third paragraph in The Concept on Readme page

trans-unit.source: Just like a painter, a photographer’s style may change over the years. Each portfolio is therefore shown in chronological order, with the latest work first.
trans-unit.target: Just like a painter, a photographer’s style may change over the years. Each portfolio is therefore shown in chronological order, with the latest work first.
trans-unit.note: Fourth paragraph in The Concept on Readme page

trans-unit.source: We try to show the portfolios with minimal distraction, just like an exposition at a museum or gallery. Web sites tend to be less optimal for this, because they are cluttered by browser controls (e.g., an address bar or tabs), and have to display multiple types of information (e.g., club news or schedules).
trans-unit.target: We try to show the portfolios with minimal distraction, just like an exposition at a museum or gallery. Web sites tend to be less optimal for this, because they are cluttered by browser controls (e.g., an address bar or tabs), and have to display multiple types of information (e.g., club news or schedules).
trans-unit.note: Fifth paragraph in The Concept on Readme page
Paragraph 3.1.a of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: _Photo Club Hub_ automatically selects its language based on your device’s language settings. It currently supports English and Dutch. You can change language using _Settings > General > Language & Region > Preferred Language Order_. Alternatively you can overrule this setting for this app only (_Settings > Photo Club Hub > Language_).
trans-unit.target: _Photo Club Hub_ automatically selects its language based on your device’s language settings. It currently supports English and Dutch. You can change language using _Settings > General > Language & Region > Preferred Language Order_. Alternatively you can overrule this setting for this app only (_Settings > Photo Club Hub > Language_).
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.1.b of the Readme screen
Paragraph 3.2.a of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: If you zoom in enough on any map, a button appears that allows you do view the scene in three dimensions. In this mode you can rotate the map.
trans-unit.target: If you zoom in enough on any map, a button appears that allows you do view the scene in three dimensions. In this mode you can rotate the map.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.2.ba of the Readme screen
Paragraph 3.3.a of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: Maps can highlight your own location as a purple dot providing that it is in range of the map. This can help navigate to a club or to estimate distances. If the map is unlocked/interactive, an arrow button let you re-center the map around your current location.
trans-unit.target: Maps can highlight your own location as a purple dot providing that it is in range of the map. This can help navigate to a club or to estimate distances. If the map is unlocked/interactive, an arrow button let you re-center the map around your current location.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.3.b of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: Live location requires granting the app __permission__ to access your location while in the app. The app doesn’t store or share location information with anyone or anything.
trans-unit.target: Live location requires granting the app __permission__ to access your location while in the app. The app doesn’t store or share location information with anyone or anything.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.3.c of the Readme screen
Paragraph 3.4.a of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: The app initially contains a set of 40+ initial photo clubs. Those clubs are currently all in one part of the Netherlands. The app, however, can support clubs anywhere in the world and the list can be extended by the users.
trans-unit.target: The app initially contains a set of 40+ initial photo clubs. Those clubs are currently all in one part of the Netherlands. The app, however, can support clubs anywhere in the world and the list can be extended by the users.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.4.b of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: For a club to be included, the app needs basic information like the club’s name and location (Level 1), a list of its members (Level 2) and links to image portfolios (Level 3). More details on extending the various lists are provided below and on GitHub.
trans-unit.target: For a club to be included, the app needs basic information like the club’s name and location (Level 1), a list of its members (Level 2) and links to image portfolios (Level 3). More details on extending the various lists are provided below and on GitHub.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.4.c of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the initial list of 30+ photo museums in various countries can also be extended by users without updating the app itself.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the initial list of 30+ photo museums in various countries can also be extended by users without updating the app itself.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.4.d of the Readme screen
Paragraph 3.5.a of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: The maps can show various photo museums throughout the world. Museums and photo clubs are distinguished by different symbols on the map. Museums show up if you zoom out any map far enough that they come into view.
trans-unit.target: The maps can show various photo museums throughout the world. Museums and photo clubs are distinguished by different symbols on the map. Museums show up if you zoom out any map far enough that they come into view.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.5.b of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: Adding a photo museum works the same way as adding a photo club - except that a museum doesn’t have members and member portfolios.
trans-unit.target: Adding a photo museum works the same way as adding a photo club - except that a museum doesn’t have members and member portfolios.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.5.c of the Readme screen
Paragraph 3.6.a of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: On the _Portfolios_ screen you can delete a club member by swiping a row to the left. The _Clubs and Museums_ screen has similar functionality for removing clubs or museums.
trans-unit.target: On the _Portfolios_ screen you can delete a club member by swiping a row to the left. The _Clubs and Museums_ screen has similar functionality for removing clubs or museums.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.6.b of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: Deletion of a member will generally be __temporary__ because the member is still on the club's online membership lists. Deletion does have effect if the entry has been removed from these online lists. The feature will be automated at some point, and is only useful in special circumstances (like when a typo in a member's name is corrected).
trans-unit.target: Deletion of a member will generally be __temporary__ because the member is still on the club's online membership lists. Deletion does have effect if the entry has been removed from these online lists. The feature will be automated at some point, and is only useful in special circumstances (like when a typo in a member's name is corrected).
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.6.c of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: So just remember that swiping to delete is harmless. And if you need to clean up a list you can alternatively simply uninstall and reinstall the app to clean up the app's internal data.
trans-unit.target: So just remember that swiping to delete is harmless. And if you need to clean up a list you can alternatively simply uninstall and reinstall the app to clean up the app's internal data.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.6.d of the Readme screen
Paragraph 3.7.a of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: This app is complimentary to your club’s web site. Because web sites have more uses than just presenting photos, _Photo Club Hub_ includes clickable links to club- and photographer web sites.
trans-unit.target: This app is complimentary to your club’s web site. Because web sites have more uses than just presenting photos, _Photo Club Hub_ includes clickable links to club- and photographer web sites.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.7.b of the Readme scree
Paragraph 3.8.a of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: When the app opens, it shows an image (“Prelude”) corresponding to the app’s icon. If you tap somewhere __inside__ the image, it zooms out to show the full image representing how digital cameras see color.
trans-unit.target: When the app opens, it shows an image (“Prelude”) corresponding to the app’s icon. If you tap somewhere __inside__ the image, it zooms out to show the full image representing how digital cameras see color.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.8.b of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: This involves a [Bayer color filter array](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayer_filter) that adds a color filter on top of each sensor cell. This filter array is shown superimposed on a colorful photo.
trans-unit.target: This involves a [Bayer color filter array](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayer_filter) that adds a color filter on top of each sensor cell. This filter array is shown superimposed on a colorful photo.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.8.c of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: Tapping __inside__ the image allows you to zoom in or out to your heart's content. Tapping __outside__ the image area ends the animation. A single tap __outside__ the image allows you to skip the animation.
trans-unit.target: Tapping __inside__ the image allows you to zoom in or out to your heart's content. Tapping __outside__ the image area ends the animation. A single tap __outside__ the image allows you to skip the animation.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.8.d of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: The animation incidentally uses GPU core acceleration using the [Metal software framework](https://browser.geekbench.com/ios-benchmarks#metal).
trans-unit.target: The animation incidentally uses GPU core acceleration using the [Metal software framework](https://browser.geekbench.com/ios-benchmarks#metal).
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.8.e of the Readme screen
Paragraph 3.9.a of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: The app can include the work of former club members. By default, former members are not shown, but you can enable displaying them in the _Preferences_ screen.
trans-unit.target: The app can include the work of former club members. By default, former members are not shown, but you can enable displaying them in the _Preferences_ screen.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.9.b of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: An easy way to get recent ex-members in the app is to simply keep their portfolio when they leave, and instead mark the member as ex-member in the membership list.
trans-unit.target: An easy way to get recent ex-members in the app is to simply keep their portfolio when they leave, and instead mark the member as ex-member in the membership list.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.9.c of the Readme screen
Paragraph 3.10.a of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: Some portfolios have an automatic slide show option. This is controlled by one of the buttons that appear when you tap on an image (this tapping is not needed on an iPad).
trans-unit.target: Some portfolios have an automatic slide show option. This is controlled by one of the buttons that appear when you tap on an image (this tapping is not needed on an iPad).
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.10.b of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: This option is available on portfolios that were generated using the _Juicebox_ plug-in for _Lightroom Classic_ (see the portfolios of Fotogroep Waalre).
trans-unit.target: This option is available on portfolios that were generated using the _Juicebox_ plug-in for _Lightroom Classic_ (see the portfolios of Fotogroep Waalre).
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.10.c of the Readme screen
Paragraph 3.11.a of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: There is a search bar at the top of all screens that display long lists. On an iPhone you may need to scroll back to the top of the list in order to see it.
trans-unit.target: There is a search bar at the top of all screens that display long lists. On an iPhone you may need to scroll back to the top of the list in order to see it.
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.11.b of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: Entering part of person’s name (for the _Portfolios_ and _Who’s Who_ screens) will find photographers with that name. The _Clubs and Museums_ screen is searched simultaneously on organization name and its town (location).
trans-unit.target: Entering part of person’s name (for the _Portfolios_ and _Who’s Who_ screens) will find photographers with that name. The _Clubs and Museums_ screen is searched simultaneously on organization name and its town (location).
trans-unit.note: Paragraph 3.11.c of the Readme screen

trans-unit.source: _Photo Club Hub_ requires the latest major version of iOS. This allows us to keep up to date technology-wise. The latest app version can run on devices released in the last 6 or 7 years.
trans-unit.target: _Photo Club Hub_ requires the latest major version of iOS. This allows us to keep up to date technology-wise. The latest app version can run on devices released in the last 6 or 7 years.
trans-unit.note: First paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: For practical reasons, the app is optimized for __iOS__ and __iPadOS__. The app can also run on MacOS or VisionOS as an iPad app.
trans-unit.target: For practical reasons, the app is optimized for __iOS__ and __iPadOS__. The app can also run on MacOS or VisionOS as an iPad app.
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Although there is presently no native support for __Android__ or other non-Apple phone platforms, we plan to provide support by automatically generating website pages from the same online lists that the app uses. This helps keep club web sites up to date, and allows viewing of clubs, members, and images in a web browsers on a wide range of platforms including Android, Windows, and more.
trans-unit.target: Although there is presently no native support for __Android__ or other non-Apple phone platforms, we plan to provide support by automatically generating website pages from the same online lists that the app uses. This helps keep club web sites up to date, and allows viewing of clubs, members, and images in a web browsers on a wide range of platforms including Android, Windows, and more.
trans-unit.note: Third paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: These and other ideas will depend on uptake and help from volunteers from the software community. If you are interested in helping, see the next section.
trans-unit.target: These and other ideas will depend on uptake and help from volunteers from the software community. If you are interested in helping, see the next section.
trans-unit.note: Fourth paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The app needs information in order to __cover your local photo club(s)__. This involves three so-called Levels. You can pause on any level before proceeding to a next level. See the app’s README file on GitHub for more details.
trans-unit.target: The app needs information in order to __cover your local photo club(s)__. This involves three so-called Levels. You can pause on any level before proceeding to a next level. See the app’s README file on GitHub for more details.
trans-unit.note: First paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: __Level 1__ requires providing the club’s name, location and a few links. As a result, the club is listed on the _Clubs and Museums_ screen and shown on its maps. If you send us the Level 1 information, we will add it to the app’s online list of clubs. Alternatively, you can submit that information (and any future updates) in the form a [GitHub “pull request”](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BCQHnlnPusY&list=PLRqwX-V7Uu6ZF9C0YMKuns9sLDzK6zoiV&index=1).
trans-unit.target: __Level 1__ requires providing the club’s name, location and a few links. As a result, the club is listed on the _Clubs and Museums_ screen and shown on its maps. If you send us the Level 1 information, we will add it to the app’s online list of clubs. Alternatively, you can submit that information (and any future updates) in the form a [GitHub “pull request”](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BCQHnlnPusY&list=PLRqwX-V7Uu6ZF9C0YMKuns9sLDzK6zoiV&index=1).
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: __Level 2__ requires providing a list of the names of current (and maybe former) club members as a text file with a specific format. This file can be stored anywhere you like as long as it can be read via a web address (URL). For example, you can store it in the _Media_ section of your club’s _Wordpress_ web site. With Level 2, the membership lists shows up on the _Portfolios_ screen. _Fotogroep Anders_ in the Netherlands is an example of a Level 2 club. We are currently simplifying Level 2 support.
trans-unit.target: __Level 2__ requires providing a list of the names of current (and maybe former) club members as a text file with a specific format. This file can be stored anywhere you like as long as it can be read via a web address (URL). For example, you can store it in the _Media_ section of your club’s _Wordpress_ web site. With Level 2, the membership lists shows up on the _Portfolios_ screen. _Fotogroep Anders_ in the Netherlands is an example of a Level 2 club. We are currently simplifying Level 2 support.
trans-unit.note: Third paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: __Level 3__ requires providing links to the online images in member portfolios. _Fotogroep Waalre_ in the Netherlands is an example of Level 3 club: you can view their portfolios via the _Portfolios_ screen. Because a club with, for example, 20 members will have hundreds of images, we have a way to automate generate portfolios using _Lightroom_ (instructions on how this works will be provided later).
trans-unit.target: __Level 3__ requires providing links to the online images in member portfolios. _Fotogroep Waalre_ in the Netherlands is an example of Level 3 club: you can view their portfolios via the _Portfolios_ screen. Because a club with, for example, 20 members will have hundreds of images, we have a way to automate generate portfolios using _Lightroom_ (instructions on how this works will be provided later).
trans-unit.note: Fourth paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Apart from onboarding clubs, there are more ways in which you can help out. Examples of __non-technical__ help include testing, writing a review for Apple’s App Store, creating user guides, and improvement ideas. Last, and certainly not least, __software development__ support will help speed up development, get fresh ideas and ensure app continuity. Example contributions include code improvement of all sorts (via [GitHub](https://github.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub), tracking down bugs, and contributing to discussions on functionality, implementation and interfaces.
trans-unit.target: Apart from onboarding clubs, there are more ways in which you can help out. Examples of __non-technical__ help include testing, writing a review for Apple’s App Store, creating user guides, and improvement ideas. Last, and certainly not least, __software development__ support will help speed up development, get fresh ideas and ensure app continuity. Example contributions include code improvement of all sorts (via [GitHub](https://github.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub), tracking down bugs, and contributing to discussions on functionality, implementation and interfaces.
trans-unit.note: Fifth paragraph Developers section of Readme page
Telephone number (usually invisible)
Name of the app shown in PreludeView when app is started
Title of page with clubs and maps

trans-unit.source: ① You can unlock/lock a map's scrolling and panning features using the Lock icon.
trans-unit.target: ① You can unlock/lock a map's scrolling and panning features using the Lock icon.
trans-unit.note: Shown in gray at the bottom of the Clubs and Museums page (1/3).

trans-unit.source: ② A photo club or museum can be deleted using swiping-left. For a photo club, this also removes its members and associated portfolios. Deleted items will reappear if the deleted items are still present online.
trans-unit.target: ② A photo club or museum can be deleted using swiping-left. For a photo club, this also removes its members and associated portfolios. Deleted items will reappear if the deleted items are still present online.
trans-unit.note: Shown in gray at the bottom of the Clubs and Museums page (2/3).
Title of page showing member portfolios

trans-unit.target: Search bar at the top of Portfolios screen

Field at top of Who's Who page that allows the user to filter the photographers based on either given- and family name.

Section title on Readme page

trans-unit.id: To see names here, please adapt the Search filter or enable additional categories on the Preferences page.
trans-unit.source: To see names here, please adapt the Search filter or enable additional categories on the Preferences page.
trans-unit.target: To see names here, please adapt the Search filter or enable additional categories on the Preferences page.

trans-unit.id: To see names here, please enable additional categories on the Preferences page.

trans-unit.target: To see names here, please enable additional categories on the Preferences page.

Caption of Localizations image on Readme page

trans-unit.id: Warning: all member categories on the Preferences page are disabled. Please enable one or more options in Preferences.
trans-unit.source: Warning: all member categories on the Preferences page are disabled. Please enable one or more options in Preferences.
trans-unit.target: Warning: all member categories on the Preferences page are disabled. Please enable one or more options in Preferences.

Title of page with list of photographers

trans-unit.source: ① This page lists all the photographers known to the app.
trans-unit.target: ① This page lists all the photographers known to the app.
trans-unit.note: Shown in gray at the bottom of the Who's Who page (1/3).

trans-unit.source: ② A photographer has one or more clickable image thumbnails below the photographer's name. Clicking on a thumbnail brings you to the image portfolio for that potographer/club combination.
trans-unit.target: ② A photographer has one or more clickable image thumbnails below the photographer's name. Clicking on a thumbnail brings you to the image portfolio for that potographer/club combination.
trans-unit.note: Shown in gray at the bottom of the Who's Who page (2/3).
